citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A rabbit was observed with clear discharge from the eyes, crusting around the nose, and rapid breathing. The rabbit was
also lethargic, kept its ears pointed back, and was isolated from the other rabbits in the enclosure. After removing the
crusty material around the nose, the rabbit still appeared to be breathing rapidly. Based on the rapid breathing and
crusting around the nose, this has likely been going on for several days. This problem was not discovered by the facility;
therefore, the attending veterinarian had not been consulted. Lack of adequate daily observations can delay veterinary
care, which negatively impacts animal welfare. The facility shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary
care that include daily observations of all animals to assess their health and well-being provided that a mechanism of
direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health,
behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. The facility must ensure that the attending veterinarian
is informed of this issue and must follow their plan for veterinary care. This issue was corrected by the facility on the day
of the inspection. To be corrected by September 12, 2024.

Numerous flies (too numerous to count) were observed in and around the enclosures housing hedgehogs, rats, ferrets,
and armadillos. Flies can transmit diseases and cause discomfort for the animals. The facility must ensure that a safe and
effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests be established and
maintained. To be corrected by September 19, 2024.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 11, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A rabbit was observed with clear discharge from the eyes, crusting around the nose, and rapid breathing. The rabbit was 
also lethargic, kept its ears pointed back, and was isolated from the other rabbits in the enclosure. After removing the 
crusty material around the nose, the rabbit still appeared to be breathing rapidly. Based on the rapid breathing and 
crusting around the nose, this has likely been going on for several days. This problem was not discovered by the facility; 
therefore, the attending veterinarian had not been consulted. Lack of adequate daily observations can delay veterinary 
care, which negatively impacts animal welfare. The facility shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary 
care that include daily observations of all animals to assess their health and well-being provided that a mechanism of 
direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, 
behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. The facility must ensure that the attending veterinarian 
is informed of this issue and must follow their plan for veterinary care. This issue was corrected by the facility on the day 
of the inspection. To be corrected by September 12, 2024. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
Numerous flies (too numerous to count) were observed in and around the enclosures housing hedgehogs, rats, ferrets, 
and armadillos. Flies can transmit diseases and cause discomfort for the animals. The facility must ensure that a safe and 
effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests be established and 
maintained. To be corrected by September 19, 2024. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 11, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
